J1.note:
Not necessarily equal to total population. 2023 UN data via the World Malaria Report (2024), Annex 4 – F:

https://www.who.int/teams/global-malaria-programme/reports/world-malaria-report-2024

K1.note:
2023 UN data, World Population Prospects (2024), via Our World in Data:

https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/population-and-demography?tab=table&facet=none&Metric=Population&Sex=Both+sexes&Age+group=Under+5+years&Projection+Scenario=None

L1.note: Excluding infants under six months old, so roughly 10% of all children under five

AL1.header: Cost of current stock of further doses required, R21 (6-60 months, USD)
AL1.note: Using prices for R21 from "Vaccine pricing"

AO1.header: Co-financing cost of current stock of further doses required, R21 (6-60 months, USD)
AO1.note:
Multiplies the number of required doses for each country by the estimated co-financing cost per dose, which is a function of the length of time a country has spent in its current co-financing phase:

– 100% for fully self-financing countries
– a flat $0.20 per dose for initial self-financing countries
– $0.20 per dose increasing by 15% per year for preparatory transition countries
– 20% of the dose price increasing by ten points per year for accelerated transition countries

More details from 1Day Africa here: https://www.1daysooner.org/how-are-vaccines-distributed-through-gavi/

AP1.note:
From the World Bank using the Atlas method, via Gavi:

https://www.gavi.org/sites/default/files/support/GNI-list-for-Gavi-website-2025.pdf

AQ1.header: Cost to avert one case, R21
AQ1.note: Over a period of a year, using the R21 efficacy at one year and the national annual case rate

AR1.header: Cost to save one life, R21
AR1.note: Over a period of a year, using the R21 efficacy at one year and the national annual death rate

AS1.note: For simplicity, calculated by dividing the current under-five population by five

AR35.header: Cost to save one life, R21
AR35.note: Undefined: São Tomé and Príncipe had no recorded malaria deaths in 2024

I1.header: Time in years since third dose
I1.note: Assuming vaccination with the first dose takes place immediately on the shipment date, and the third dose two months later

J1.note: Accounting for waning vaccine efficacy between the third dose and the current date, linearly interpolated based on the data in the "Vaccine efficacy curves" sheet

M1.note: Assuming a linear ramp-up from 0% coverage on the shipment date to 100% coverage six months after the shipment date, equivalent to an instantaneous roll-out after a three-month delay

N1.note: Assuming a linear ramp-up from 0% coverage on the shipment date to 100% coverage six months after the shipment date, equivalent to an instantaneous roll-out after a three-month delay

O1.note: Integrates [vaccine efficacy x number of children covered] over time, with efficacy data taken from "Vaccine efficacy curves"

P1.note: Integrates [vaccine efficacy x number of children covered] over time, with efficacy data taken from "Vaccine efficacy curves"

Q1.header: Cases averted so far (six-month roll-out, waning efficacy)
Q1.note:
Integrates [vaccine efficacy x number of children covered] over time, with efficacy data taken from "Vaccine efficacy curves"

Also assumes a linear ramp-up from 0% coverage on the shipment date to 100% coverage six months after the shipment date, equivalent to an instantaneous roll-out after a three-month delay

R1.header: Lives saved so far (six-month roll-out, waning efficacy)
R1.note:
Integrates [vaccine efficacy x number of children covered] over time, with efficacy data taken from "Vaccine efficacy curves"

Also assumes a linear ramp-up from 0% coverage on the shipment date to 100% coverage six months after the shipment date, equivalent to an instantaneous roll-out after a three-month delay

A2.note:
Data from the RTS,S Clinical Trials Partnership in their 2015 Lancet paper:

https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(15)60721-8/abstract

Via Duncombe, Elabd and Sandefur (2024), p.3:

https://www.cgdev.org/sites/default/files/avoiding-another-lost-decade-malaria-vaccines.pdf

A3.note:
Data from Datoo et al. (2024) in The Lancet:

https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(23)02511-4/fulltext?s=08

Via Duncombe, Elabd and Sandefur, p.3:

https://www.cgdev.org/sites/default/files/avoiding-another-lost-decade-malaria-vaccines.pdf

A2.note:
Data from Malawi's roll-out of RTS,S through MVIP

See p.49: 

https://cdn.who.int/media/docs/default-source/immunization/mvip/full-evidence-report-on-the-rtss-as01-malaria-vaccine-for-sage-mpag-%28sept2021%29.pdf

A4.note:
Data from South Sudan's roll-out of R21:

https://www.afro.who.int/countries/south-sudan/news/south-sudan-launches-second-phase-r21-malaria-vaccine-introduction-52-counties-protect-children
